<form onsubmit="event.preventDefault(); checkAnswer('module7_mcq_q31')" data-correct-answer="E">
<strong style="display: block;">According to Modigliani and Miller Proposition II (no taxes), what is the main reason why a firm's cost of equity increases with higher leverage?</strong>

<label><input type="radio" name="module7_mcq_q31" value="A"> A. Because leverage increases the firm’s total business risk.</label><br>
<label><input type="radio" name="module7_mcq_q31" value="B"> B. Because the cost of debt increases proportionally with the cost of equity.</label><br>
<label><input type="radio" name="module7_mcq_q31" value="C"> C. Because the firm’s unlevered cost of capital rises with leverage.</label><br>
<label><input type="radio" name="module7_mcq_q31" value="D"> D. Because equity investors receive a smaller portion of the firm’s profits when debt increases.</label><br>
<label><input type="radio" name="module7_mcq_q31" value="E"> E. Because leverage amplifies the variability of equity returns, increasing the required return to compensate for higher financial risk.</label><br>
</form>

<div id="feedback-module7_mcq_q31" class="feedback" data-status="" style="display:none;">
✅ Correct: E.  
Under MM Proposition II (no taxes), the cost of equity increases with leverage because shareholders face greater financial risk.  
Although the firm’s total risk ($r_U$) remains constant, debt introduces fixed obligations, making residual cash flows to equity more volatile.  
This relationship is formalized as $r_E = r_U + \frac{D}{E}(r_U - r_D)$.
</div>
